messages.message: As a wider question; are we able to support currently any deployments in the Turkish region? I understand from speaking with @Jason that we could theoretically support Equinix (in an OpenShift deployment as we have done so in the past) - would this be an option we can float forwards?
cc @Darragh Byrne incase you missed this

I would strongly recommend that we invest our time and efforts in pursuing opportunities with partners that accept one of our officially supported SaaS deployment configurations.

It is not a good idea for us to be entertaining OpenShift deployments for any prospective customer or prospect.

@Matt Weaver - agreed - questions is, what is the best architecture for the region considering hosting requirements, latency and cost. What would it mean to host out of the AWS Dubai region (with the official confg) for example, what can we mount to locally from a storage perspective if there are data residency concerns etc.

My understanding from the Isbank engagement is that Cloud is basically a no-go in Turkey altogether for our kind of target customers....
https://www.lexology.com/library/detail.aspx?g=cf834918-dcde-4815-8f69-cf840651c1d1
> *Legislation and regulation*
> _Recognition of concept_
> *Is cloud computing specifically recognised and provided for in your legal system? If so, how?*
> There is no legal definition of cloud computing technologies. Yet, there are references to cloud computing technologies or services within the scopes of personal data protection, data localisation and cybersecurity for public institutions and companies operating in certain sectors such as finance, energy and electronic communications.
> _Governing legislation_
> *Does legislation or regulation directly and specifically prohibit, restrict or otherwise govern cloud computing, in or outside your jurisdiction?*
> Presidential Circular No. 2019/12 (Circular), published and entered into force on 6 July 2019, sets out information and communications security measures to be applied by public institutions, public organisations and undertakings providing critical infrastructure services. Critical infrastructure sectors are energy, electronic communications, banking and finance, transportation, water management and critical public services (eg, national security, healthcare). As per the Circular, public institutions and organisations shall not store their data in cloud storage services except for their own private systems or local service providers controlled by the institutions themselves

FWIW, OpenShift deployments are client-managed.  Only if a client or partner already knows how to run large, microservice software platforms in OpenShift would it possibly be successful.  In OpenShift/client-managed, we simply provide requirements about what needs to be set up and how a software deploy works.  We do not do any of that for them.  The client truly manages their infrastructure and Instabase deployment.

Rightâ€¦ but in a world of AI Hub, it still becomes a big burden for us to support customers who try to do this themselves. So the deal size would need to be very large for us to even entertain it (>$1.5m)
I suggest we focus our efforts on other markets at this stage :earth_americas:

No question there.  I don't know of a single organization outside of us that knows how to run our size of application in their environment.  I meant to communicate that this will be hard and us supporting them does not imply that they don't do any work.  It usually ends in tears regardless of whether it is ultimately successful.

This partner operates in Turkey, Spain, Italy and the UAE, so we wont be focused on just Turkey (its not my preference) so if the consensus is a hard no for Turkey, thats fine. in our response we it would be good to support them with other considerations for the regions they operate (most interesting for me is what would Dubai AWS look like?) they work with some of the big banks there
